answers.text: this is done to give wrestlers a break from the action

qas.question: What happens in a fatal four-way?

answers.text: four wrestlers, each for themselves, fight in a match, but only two wrestlers can be in the match at any given time.

qas.question: In a fatal four-way, who can make tags?

answers.text: tags can be made between any two wrestlers.

qas.question: What was the most common type of match before the fatal four-way?

context: Sometimes, poly-sided matches that pit every one for themselves will incorporate tagging rules. Outside of kayfabe, <a0_0>this is done to give wrestlers a break from the action<a0_0/> (as these matches tend to go on for long periods of time), and to make the action in the ring easier to choreograph. One of the most mainstream examples of this is the <a3_0>four-corner match<a3_0/>, the most common type of match in the WWE before it was replaced with its equivalent fatal four-way; <a1_0>four wrestlers, each for themselves, fight in a match, but only two wrestlers can be in the match at any given time.<a1_0/> The other two are positioned in the corner, and <a2_0>tags can be made between any two wrestlers.
